The lower the recombination rate, the less likely the two genes will be separated and the closer they will be with respect to each other on the chromosome. Since the recombination rate is close to 0%, the probability that the two genes will be separated is very unlikely which means they are spatially very close together.

question.text: Each of the following are true concerning Down’s syndrome EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: C.
options.text: Produced due to an increased number of chromosome 21

options.label: D.
options.text: Generally does not run in families

explanation.concept_text: " Frequency increases with mitotic division " is a false statement because the most common cause of Down syndrome is nondisjunction during meiosis, which occurs during gamete formation. This produces full Trisomy 21, whereby each cell of an individual with Down syndrome will have an extra copy of chromosome #21. While nondisjunction can also occur in mitosis, this does not contribute to the frequency of full Trisomy 21.

question.text: A pedigree diagram shows only females passing a disease to all offspring despite their sex. Affected males do not pass the disease to their offspring. The trait is most likely ___________.

explanation.concept_text: Mitochondrial diseases are inherited from the mother due to the fact that mitochondria are maternally inherited . This is because the zygote’s mitochondria are the mitochondria of the oocyte which means that sperm mitochondria do not contribute to the zygote’s pool of mitochondria. An affected mother will pass on this disease to all offspring, but an affected father will not pass on the disease at all. CC By 4.0

question.text: Draw out a recombination map based on the information: 1. A and B are 10 map units away 2. A and C are 20 map units away 3. C and D are 14 map units away

explanation.concept_text: The distance between A and C must be the longest which would place A and C at each end of the recombination map . B will be located between the 10 map units away from A and 10 map units away from B. D is 14 map units away from C which means D will be located between A and B since B is only 10 map units away from C and A is 20 map units away from C.

question.text: The pedigree below demonstrates which inheritance pattern?

explanation.concept_text: Since mitochondria are maternally inherited , an affected mother will pass on mitochondrial disease to all of her offspring. However, an affected male will not have any affected children due to the fact that paternal mitochondria are not passed down to the offspring. CC By 4.0

question.text: The pedigree diagram below follows which inheritance pattern?

explanation.concept_text: X-linked dominant inheritance patterns can be recognized by affected males having all female offspring affected. Since males only have one X chromosome, they will only pass on the mutant X chromosome to all daughters. Since it is a dominant inheritance pattern, they will be affected. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following best describes how an x-linked dominant trait appears on a pedigree?

options.label: C.
options.text: The female offspring of affected males have the dominant trait

options.label: D.
options.text: The male affected offspring do not have affected mothers

correct_answer_text: The female offspring of affected males have the dominant trait

explanation.concept_text: Affected males only have one X chromosome and it has the mutated copy of the gene. Therefore, all female offspring of this male will be affected since the male can only pass the X chromosome down to the female offspring.

question.text: Which of the following will be shown on a pedigree of a Y-linked trait?

options.label: B.
options.text: All females will have a lethal gene

options.label: C.
options.text: All male offspring of an affected father will be affected

options.label: D.
options.text: All female offspring of an affected father will be affected

options.label: E.
options.text: All offspring of an affected mother will be affected

correct_answer_text: All male offspring of an affected father will be affected

explanation.concept_text: An affected male with a Y-linked disorder will pass on a normal X chromosome to female offspring and a mutated Y chromosome to male offspring. Since males only have one copy of the Y chromosome, all male offspring of an affected father will also be affected. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following is true concerning x-linked recessive diseases?

options.label: A.
options.text: Females are more phenotypically susceptible to the disease

options.label: B.
options.text: Males are more phenotypically susceptible to the disease

options.label: C.
options.text: Male offspring of an affected father will receive the disease

options.label: D.
options.text: X-linked recessive diseases can never skip generations

options.label: E.
options.text: X-linked recessive diseases always appear in females

correct_answer_text: Males are more phenotypically susceptible to the disease

explanation.concept_text: For X-linked recessive diseases , females must have both copies of their X chromosomes affected since only one affected copy will allow the normal copy to mask the mutated recessive allele . However, males only have one copy of the X chromosome , so if they receive a copy of a mutated allele, they will not have a normal/wild-type copy to mask the mutant copy. The lack of second X chromosomes in males makes them more susceptible to X-linked recessive disorders.

question.text: Which of the following is a common occurrence for autosomal recessive diseases?

options.label: A.
options.text: The trait always appears in all offspring

options.label: C.
options.text: Only the affected males pass the disease to their offspring

options.label: D.
options.text: Only the affected females pass the disease to their offspring

options.label: E.
options.text: Only the male offspring are affected by affected fathers

explanation.concept_text: For autosomal recessive diseases , an individual must have two mutated copies of the gene to be affected by the disease. If an individual only has one copy of the mutated gene, the wild-type copy will mask the mutant copy. If two individuals are both heterozygous for the gene (one wild-type and one mutant copy). There is a 25% chance that they will both pass down the mutant gene to the offspring which will result in two unaffected parents having an affected offspring. This phenomenon is known as generation-skipping . CC By 4.0

question.text: If a woman is blood type A and a man is blood type A, which of the following are the possible blood types of their child?

explanation.concept_text: Since A blood is dominant over O blood, an individual with type A blood can either have an AA genotype is they have two A alleles, or they could also be AO is they have an A allele and an O allele. CC By 4.0 CC By 4.0 If either parent has two type A genes, the only possible blood type is A. However, if both parents are heterozygous (AO), this will allow the OO genotype to emerge in the offspring, there is therefore a ¼ chance that a child is born with type O blood if we assume that both parents have the AO genotype. CC By 4.0

question.text: If a child and his six siblings are all blood type O, then which of the following is the most likely blood type of his parents?

explanation.concept_text: For two individuals to continuously have children that are type O blood , it is likely that both parents have type O blood due to the fact that individuals with type O blood have two copies of the type O gene and no copies of any other blood types. This means that two parents that both have type O blood can only produce children with type O blood CC By 4.0

question.text: A woman is blood type A and a man is blood type B. Which of the following are the possible blood types of their children?

explanation.concept_text: A and B blood types are both dominant over type O but codominant to each other. Therefore, an individual with type A blood can either have an AA genotype or an AO genotype and an individual with type B blood can either have a BB genotype or a BO genotype. We can assume that both parents carry a copy of the recessive type O allele (AO and BO parents) to allow for the most variety in possible blood types in the offspring. This is because if an AO individual has children with a BO individual, there will be a chance for the two O alleles to come together to produce an offspring that has O blood. If we assume an AO-BO cross, there is a ¼ chance of producing each blood type. CC By 4.0 CC By 4.0

question.text: If both parents are blood type AB, then what are the possible blood types of their children?

explanation.concept_text: Individuals with type AB blood have one type A gene, one type B gene and no type O gene. CC By 4.0

question.text: If one parent is blood type O and the other AB, then what are the possible blood types of their children?

explanation.concept_text: A and B blood are dominant over type O blood. The parent with type O blood has two recessive type O genes and can therefore only pass down a type O gene. The type AB parent can either pass down the type A or the type B gene. There will therefore be a ½ chance to produce a child with type A blood and a ½ chance to produce a child with type B blood. CC By 4.0

question.text: If one parent is blood type A and the other has blood type O, then what are the possible blood types of their children?

explanation.concept_text: Since A blood is dominant over O blood, an individual with type A blood can have two type A genes or one type A gene and one type O gene. CC By 4.0 CC By 4.0 If either parent has two type A genes, the only possible blood type is A. However, if both parents have one type A gene and one type O gene, then there is a ¼ chance that a child is born with type O blood. CC By 4.0

question.text: Dry earwax (D) is dominant over wet earwax (d). A woman with dry earwax marries a man with wet earwax and they conceive a child with wet earwax. What is the genotype of the woman?

explanation.concept_text: A child with wet earwax must have both copies of the wet earwax gene since it is recessive to dry earwax. Therefore, the genotype of the child must be dd. Since the mother has dry earwax, her genotype can either be homozygous dominant (DD) or heterozygous (Dd). But, since the child inherited a wet earwax gene from both parents, the mother’s genotype must be Dd CC By 4.0 CC By 4.0

question.text: If a homozygous green (GG) flower and a homozygous white (gg) flower are crossed, then what is the genotype of their offspring?

explanation.concept_text: The homozygous green flower can only pass down a G allele while the homozygous white flower can only pass down a g allele. Therefore, the only possibility for the genotype of the offspring is Gg. CC By 4.0

question.text: If two color-blind parents produce offspring, what is the chance their child will be colorblind?

explanation.concept_text: Colorblindness is an X-linked recessive disorder. If we define X c as the mutant allele, a colorblind female will have the genotype: X c X c and a colorblind male will have the genotype: X c Y Male offspring only inherit one X chromosome which is from the mother. Since both maternal X chromosomes are mutant, the sons will all be colorblind. Female offspring have two X chromosomes, one coming from the mother and the other from the father. Since all maternal and paternal X chromosomes are mutant, all daughters will be colorblind. CC By 4.0

question.text: If two normal non-carrier parents mate, what is the chance their child will be a colorblind daughter?

explanation.concept_text: If an individual is unaffected and not a carrier , they carry two wild-type copies of the gene and no mutant copies. When two normal, non-carrier parents mate, they cannot produce any affected offspring due to the fact that neither parent can pass down a mutant allele. CC By 4.0

question.text: If AA x aa is crossed, what is the chance of heterozygous offspring?

explanation.concept_text: A homozygous dominant individual (AA) can only pass down an “A” allele and a homozygous recessive individual (aa) can only pass down an “a” allele. This means that there is only one possibility for the genotype of the offspring which is a heterozygous genotype (Aa) CC By 4.0

question.text: If two heterozygous organisms are crossed, what is the chance of heterozygous offspring?

explanation.concept_text: A heterozygous individual has one dominant and one recessive allele. A Punnett square is used to determine the genotypic frequencies of the possible offspring. Since two out of the four squares have a heterozygous genotype, the probability of having a heterozygous offspring is 50%. CC By 4.0

question.text: If a homozygous dominant organism and the homozygous recessive organism are crossed, what is the chance of heterozygous offspring?

explanation.concept_text: A homozygous dominant individual (AA) can only pass down an “A” allele and a homozygous recessive individual (aa) can only pass down an “a” allele. This means that there is only one possibility for the genotype of the offspring which is a heterozygous genotype (Aa). CC By 4.0

question.text: If a homozygous dominant organism is crossed with a heterozygous organism, what is the chance of a homozygous recessive offspring?

explanation.concept_text: A homozygous recessive individual has two copies of the recessive allele which means that they must inherit a recessive allele from both parents. Since the homozygous dominant organism has two copies of the dominant allele and no copies of the recessive allele, the probability of a homozygous dominant and a heterozygous individual having a homozygous recessive offspring is 0%. CC By 4.0

question.text: If a homozygous recessive organism is crossed with a heterozygous organism, what is the chance of a homozygous recessive offspring?

explanation.concept_text: A homozygous recessive induvial has two copies of the recessive allele and must receive a recessive copy from each parent. The homozygous recessive (aa) individual has a 100% chance of passing down the recessive allele and the heterozygous individual (Aa) has a 50% chance of passing down the recessive allele. According to the Punnett square below, two out of the four squares (or 50%) have a homozygous recessive genotype. CC By 4.0

question.text: Tall (T) traits in plants are dominant over short (t) plants. What is the chance of short offspring if a homozygous dominant plant is crossed with a heterozygote plant?

explanation.concept_text: Since the short phenotype is recessive, a plant must have two copies of the recessive short allele (t) to be a short plant. This means that it must receive a “t” allele from each parent. Since a homozygous dominant plant has two copies of the dominant allele (TT), it will only pass down a dominant “T” allele which means all offspring will be tall. CC By 4.0

question.text: Yellow (Y) color peas are dominant over green (y) color pea plants. If a green pea plant is crossed with a heterozygous yellow color pea plant, then what is the chance their offspring will be green?

explanation.concept_text: Since green is the recessive trait, an organism must have two copies of the green (y) allele to be green The green plant can only pass down a green (y) allele, but the yellow heterozygous plant (Yy) only has a 50% chance of passing down a green allele. This means that there is a 50% chance of these organisms producing a green offspring CC By 4.0

question.text: If one parent is heterozygous for the mutated Huntington’s disease gene but the other parent is normal, what is the chance that their offspring will develop Huntington’s disease?

explanation.concept_text: Huntington’s disease is an autosomal dominant disease which means an individual only needs one copy of the mutated gene to be affected by the disease. The normal parent is unaffected by the disease and there cannot pass down a mutated allele . However, the heterozygous parent (Hh) has a 50% chance of passing down the mutated allele (H) thus giving these parents a 50% chance of having offspring that will be affected by Huntington’s disease CC By 4.0

question.text: If two parents are heterozygous for the mutated Huntington’s disease gene, what is the chance their offspring will not develop Huntington’s disease?

explanation.concept_text: Huntington’s disease is an autosomal dominant disease which means an individual only needs one copy of the mutated gene to be affected by the disease. Since both parents are heterozygous (Hh) for Huntington’s gene, both parents have a 50% of passing down the normal allele (h). To calculate the total probability, we multiply the individual probabilities: (1/2)(1/2) = 1/4 or 25% CC By 4.0

question.text: If a mother has three sons in a row, what is the possibility that her next child will also be a son?

explanation.concept_text: The probabilities of the sex of children are independent events meaning that the probability for the sex of the next child is not affected by the previous. The probability of having a son is 1/2, thus the probability of her fourth child being a boy is also 1/2 (50%)

question.text: A mother has eleven daughters in a row. What is the possibility that her next child will not be a daughter, but a son?

explanation.concept_text: The probabilities of the sex of children are independent events meaning that the probability for the sex of the next child is not affected by the previous. The probability of having a son is 1/2, thus the probability of her twelfth child being a boy is also 1/2 (50%).

question.text: What inheritance pattern is most likely shown in the pedigree chart below?

explanation.concept_text: Autosomal dominant diseases appear in every generation due to the fact that an individual only needs one copy of the mutant allele to be affected. This prevents individuals from acting as carriers. When an affected father has both male and female offspring that are affected, this is a sign that the disease follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

question.text: What is the genotype of individual A?

explanation.concept_text: All children of individual A are affected which means the disease most likely follows an autosomal dominant inheritance . Since all of the children are affected, it is likely that both alleles of the individual are the mutant form which would make their genotype AA.

question.text: What is the genotype of individual B?

explanation.concept_text: All children of individual A are affected which means the disease most likely follows an autosomal dominant inheritance . Individual B is not affected, they do not have a copy of the mutant allele and therefore have two copies of the recessive allele, making the genotype aa.

question.text: What is the genotype of individual C?

explanation.concept_text: All children of individual A are affected which means the disease most likely follows an autosomal dominant inheritance . Individual C has a child that is unaffected, the unaffected child must have received a wild-type recessive allele from each parent. But, since individual C is affected, their genotype must be Aa.

question.text: What is the genotype of individual D?

explanation.concept_text: All children of individual A are affected which means the disease most likely follows an autosomal dominant inheritance . Individual D is affected, so they either have a heterozygous or homozygous dominant genotype . However, since one of the parents of individual D is unaffected, the unaffected parent has a homozygous recessive genotype so they can only pass down the wild-type recessive allele. This means that individual D must be heterozygous (Aa).

question.text: If individual D produces offspring with an unaffected female, what is the chance their child will also be unaffected by the studied trait??

explanation.concept_text: All children of individual A are affected which means the disease most likely follows an autosomal dominant inheritance . Individual D as the genotype Aa since they are affected and have an unaffected parent and an unaffected female would have a homozygous recessive (aa) genotype. When a monohybrid cross is performed using a Punnett square, two out of the four squares are homozygous recessive meaning that those children would be unaffected. Therefore, the probability is 2/4 = 1/2. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following inheritance patterns does the pedigree chart follow?

explanation.concept_text: The inheritance pattern of this disease is autosomal recessive due to the fact that individual C  and his partner are both unaffected yet have an affected child. This means that individual C and his partner must both be carriers showing that 2 mutant alleles are required for an individual to be affected. CC By 4.0

question.text: What is the genotype of individual A?

explanation.concept_text: The inheritance pattern of this disease is autosomal recessive due to the fact that individual C  and his partner are both unaffected yet have an affected child. This means that for an individual to be affected, they must have two copies of the mutant allele. Individual A is affected and therefore must have both copies of the mutant allele which would make the individual have a homozygous recessive genotype (aa).

question.text: What is the genotype of individual B?

explanation.concept_text: The inheritance pattern of this disease is autosomal recessive due to the fact that individual C  and his partner are both unaffected yet have an affected child. This means that for an individual to be affected, they must have two copies of the mutant allele . Individual B is not affected and can therefore be homozygous dominant or heterozygous . Since Individual B has affected children who are homozygous recessive, those children had to have received a mutant allele from both parents which would make individual B have a heterozygous genotype (Aa). CC By 4.0

question.text: What is the genotype of individual C?

explanation.concept_text: The inheritance pattern of this disease is autosomal recessive due to the fact that individual C  and his partner are both unaffected yet have an affected child. This means that for an individual to be affected, they must have two copies of the mutant allele . Individual C is not affected and can therefore be homozygous dominant or heterozygous . Since Individual C has an affected child who must be homozygous recessive, the child must have received a mutant allele from both parents which would make individual B have a heterozygous genotype (Aa). CC By 4.0

question.text: What is the genotype of individual D?

explanation.concept_text: The inheritance pattern of this disease is autosomal recessive due to the fact that individual C  and his partner are both unaffected yet have an affected child. This means that for an individual to be affected, they must have two copies of the mutant allele. Individual D is affected and therefore must have both copies of the mutant allele which would make the individual have a homozygous recessive genotype (aa).

question.text: What is the genotype of individual E?

explanation.concept_text: The inheritance pattern of this disease is autosomal recessive due to the fact that individual C  and his partner are both unaffected yet have an affected child. This means that for an individual to be affected, they must have two copies of the mutant allele. Individual E is affected and therefore must have two copies of the mutant allele which would make the individual have a homozygous recessive genotype (aa).

question.text: If individual E meets an affected male, then what is the chance their offspring will be affected as well?

explanation.concept_text: The inheritance pattern of this disease is autosomal recessive due to the fact that individual C  and his partner are both unaffected yet have an affected child. This means that for an individual to be affected, they must have two copies of the mutant allele . If individual E is affected and the male she meets will also be affected. This means that both induvial must have two copies of the mutant allele and thus have homozygous recessive genotypes. When crossed using a Punnett square , both individuals can only pass down the recessive allele and therefore can only produce affected offspring. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following inheritance patterns does the pedigree chart most likely follow?

We can confirm the disease is specifically X-linked recessive because the affected male on the left side of the pedigree passes on his mutant X chromosome to his daughter, yet she is unaffected. This means only individuals with 2 copies of the mutant allele are affected, which is consistent with recessive conditions.

question.text: If two normal parents have four kids with sickle cell anemia, what is the probability that their next child will also have sickle cell anemia?

explanation.concept_text: Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder which means that an individual needs two copies of the recessive allele to be affected. If the two parents are normal, yet have a child with sickle cell anemia, this implies that both parents must be carriers to pass on the recessive allele to the child. A Punnett square where the two carriers (heterozygote) parents can be crossed to determine the probability of the next child being affected by sickle cell anemia. Since only one out of the four squares has the sickle cell anemia phenotype, the probability is equal to 1/4 CC By 4.0

question.text: If two normal parents produce a hemophilic son, then what is the genotype of the parents?

options.label: A.
options.text: X A X A and X A Y

options.label: B.
options.text: X A X A and X a Y

options.label: C.
options.text: X a X a and X a Y

options.label: D.
options.text: X A X a and X a Y

options.label: E.
options.text: X A X a and X A Y

correct_answer_text: X A X a and X A Y

explanation.concept_text: Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder which means that females need both copies of the mutant X chromosome and males only need one copy due to the lack of a second X chromosome. If both parents are normal, the father must be X A Y since males cannot be carriers due to only having one X chromosome. However, the mother’s genotype must be determined by looking at the son’s genotype. The son’s genotype is X a Y since he is affected. This means that the son inherited the Y chromosome from the father and the X a chromosome from the mother, but since the mother is normal, she must be a heterozygote (X A X a )

question.text: Which of the following is true concerning calico cats?

options.label: A.
options.text: Males calico cats have Barr bodies

options.label: B.
options.text: Male cats are mutated against the tri-color gene

options.label: D.
options.text: Genetic recombination produces the calico coloration

options.label: E.
options.text: Calico coloration is caused by random mutations

explanation.concept_text: Calico cats are a domestic breed of cat with a coat that contains three different colors. The colour differences arise from a phenomenon known as X-chromosome inactivation . This is a phenomenon where one of the X chromosomes in the cell becomes inactive and forms a Barr body and thus is only observed in females since females have two X chromosomes. Depending on which X chromosome becomes inactive, different colors can arise.

question.text: Where is the Barr body found in the human body?

explanation.concept_text: The Barry Body is found in somatic female cells. A Barr body is a structure formed from an inactive X chromosome . In female somatic cells that contain two X chromosomes, one will always randomly inactivate. CC By 4.0

question.text: Two parents are carriers of cystic fibrosis. What is the chance that their child will also be a carrier of cystic fibrosis?

explanation.concept_text: Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder meaning that an individual needs two copies of the mutant allele to be affected. If both parents are carriers, their genotypes are heterozygous. By using a Punnett square to cross two heterozygous parents, it is found that two out of the four boxes will result in a carrier offspring. Therefore, the probability is 2/4 = 1/2 CC By 4.0

question.text: A hemophilia carrier female and an unaffected male produce two boys with hemophilia. What is the chance that their next son will have hemophilia?

explanation.concept_text: Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder which means that females need both copies of the mutant X chromosome and males only need the one copy due to the lack of a second X chromosome. If a hemophilia carrier female is crossed with an unaffected male using a Punnett square, one out of two males is affected by hemophilia making the probability equal 1/2 CC By 4.0

question.text: A hemophilia carrier female and an unaffected male produce a carrier female. The carrier daughter has a son with an affected male. What is the chance that this son will not be affected?

explanation.concept_text: Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder which means that females need both copies of the mutant X chromosome to be affected and males only need one copy due to the lack of a second X chromosome. If a hemophilia carrier female has a son with an affected male, we can determine the probability of having an unaffected son by using a Punnett square . In the image below, one out of the two sons are unaffected, therefore the probability of the son being unaffected is ½. Note that we do not need to also include the probability of having a son in our calculatiuon, as the question already tells us the couple has had one. We only need to account for the outcome where the son is affected. CC By 4.0

question.text: Rett Syndrome is an X-linked dominant disease. If an unaffected female mates with an affected male, then what is the chance their daughter will have the disease?

explanation.concept_text: An X-linked dominant disease is a type of disease where an individual only needs one copy of the mutant allele to be affected. Since every daughter will receive an X chromosome from the father and the father's X chromosome carries the dominant allele for the trait, all daughters will be affected. CC By 4.0

question.text: Focal dermal hypoplasia is an X-linked dominant disease. An unaffected female meets a man whose father had focal dermal hypoplasia and an unaffected mother. What is the chance that their daughter will have focal dermal hypoplasia?

explanation.concept_text: An X-linked dominant disease is a type of disease where an individual only needs one copy of the mutant allele to be affected. The mother is unaffected and therefore does not have the mutant allele to pass down to her offspring. Since the father’s mother is unaffected, the father must have inherited a normal X chromosome. Therefore, since the mother and father are both unaffected, the probability of having a daughter with focal dermal hypoplasia is 0% CC By 4.0

question.text: A man and his maternal grandfather both have colorblindness. The man marries a normal woman who is not a carrier for colorblindness. What is the chance their son will also have colorblindness?

explanation.concept_text: Colorblindness is an X-linked recessive disorder which means that females need both copies of the mutant X chromosome to be affected and males only need one copy due to the lack of a second X chromosome. When a Punnett square is used to cross a colorblind male with a normal female, no colorblind sons are possible. CC By 4.0

question.text: If a woman is a carrier of the colorblindness gene and marries a normal man, then which of the following statements is true?

options.label: B.
options.text: All females will be colorblindness carriers

options.label: C.
options.text: The chance of male offspring having colorblindness is 50%

options.label: D.
options.text: The chance of male offspring colorblindness is 25%

options.label: E.
options.text: The chance of female offspring colorblindness is 75%

correct_answer_text: The chance of male offspring having colorblindness is 50%

explanation.concept_text: Colorblindness is an X-linked recessive disorder which means that females need both copies of the mutant X chromosome to be affected and males only need one copy due to the lack of a second X chromosome. When a Punnett square is used to cross a normal male with a carrier female, the chance of a male being colorblind is 50% CC By 4.0

question.text: A male and female are unaffected by an X-linked dominant disease. Which of the following is true?

options.label: A.
options.text: Their daughters will be a carrier of the disease

options.label: B.
options.text: Their sons will be a carrier of the disease

options.label: C.
options.text: Their offspring will not be affected by the disease

options.label: D.
options.text: Their offspring will all be carriers of the disease

options.label: E.
options.text: Their offspring will all be affected by the disease

correct_answer_text: Their offspring will not be affected by the disease

explanation.concept_text: An X-linked dominant disease is a type of disease where an individual only needs one copy of the mutant allele to be affected. If both the male and the female are unaffected by the disease, that means that neither of them carries the mutant allele which means neither of them can pass down the disease to their offspring. CC By 4.0

question.text: In a specific amphibian, long legs are only expressed when the genotype is heterozygous. If two heterozygous organisms are mated together, then what is the chance the offspring will have long legs?

explanation.concept_text: A Punnett square can be used to cross two heterozygous individuals to determine the probability of the offspring being heterozygous. Since two out of the four squares have offspring with a heterozygous genotype, the probability of having an offspring that is heterozygous (long legs) is equal to 2/4 = 50% CC By 4.0

question.text: Yellow (Y) color in pea plants is dominant over green (y) color. A botanist would like to determine the genotype of an unknown plant. What genotype should she test cross with the unknown plant?

explanation.concept_text: A test cross is performed to explore the unknown genotype of an organism. The unknown plant must be yellow since yellow can have two possible genotypes (YY or Yy) whereas green can only have one possible genotype (yy). To determine the unknown genotype of the yellow plant a test cross can be performed with a homozygous recessive plant (yy) as this can expose the recessive green allele in a heterozygous yellow plant. If all offspring are yellow, then the unknown genotype was YY and if the offspring exist in a 1:1 ratio of yellow: green, then the unknown genotype was Yy. CC By 4.0

question.text: Brown (B) eyes in humans are dominant over blue (b) eyes. If a heterozygous, brown-eyed man marries a blue-eyed woman, then what is the probability two children in a row will have blue eyes?

explanation.concept_text: Since brown eyes are dominant to blue eyes, an individual needs two copies of the blue eyes allele (b) to have the blue eyes phenotype. When a Punnett square is used to cross a heterozygous man with a blue-eyed woman, who must be homozygous recessive , two out of four squares have blue-eyed offspring which equals a probability of 2/4 = 1/2. But, to calculate the probability of two children in a row with blue eyes, The probability of the first child being born with blue eyes must be multiplied by the probability of the second child being born with blue eyes. Since both probabilities are equal, 1/2 is multiplied by 1/2 to get 1/4 = 25% CC By 4.0

question.text: Brown (B) eyes in humans are dominant over blue (b) eyes. A brown-eyed man marries a blue-eyed woman. The man’s mother is blue-eyed, and his father is brown-eyed. What is the probability the married couple will have a child with blue eyes?

explanation.concept_text: Since brown eyes are dominant to blue eyes, an individual needs two copies of the blue eyes allele (b) to have the blue eyes phenotype . The brown-eyed father has a mother who has blue eyes and therefore has two copies of the blue eyes allele. Therefore, the father’s mother must have passed down a blue eyes allele making the father heterozygous . When a Punnett square is used to cross a heterozygous brown-eyed male with a homozygous recessive blue-eyed female, two out of the four squares have offspring that have the blue-eyed phenotype, making the probability equal 2/4 = 50%. CC By 4.0 CC By 4.0
